Brooklyn Historical Society
Daniel and Hugh Friel letters
Friel, Daniel
Friel, Hugh
1977.425
0.06 Linear Feet in one folder.
1858-1866 This collection includes letters from Daniel and Hugh Friel to their family, in which they address business affairs, personal matters, and their experiences fighting in the Civil War. The collection includes the original letters along with typed transcriptions. The letters span 1858 to 1866. Daniel and Hugh Friel immigrated to Brooklyn from Ireland and lived on the corner of Classon and Lafayette Streets. A0069
Processing Information
Minimally processed to the collection level.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date (if known); Daniel and Hugh Friel letters, 1977.425, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.
Biographical Note
Daniel and Hugh Friel immigrated to Brooklyn from Ireland and lived on the corner of Classon and Lafayette Streets. Daniel, the eldest brother, had served in the U.S. Navy on the Frigate Wabash before serving in the Civil War as Second Lieutenant in the 47th New York Volunteers. After the War, he returned to Brooklyn and became a fireman. Hugh also served in the Civil War, enlisting in the 158th New York Volunteers as a drummer boy. He later resided at the Old Soldiers Home in Bath, N.Y., where he died at an advanced age.
Scope and Contents
This collection includes letters from Daniel and Hugh Friel to their family, in which they address business affairs, personal matters, and their experiences fighting in the Civil War. The collection includes the original letters along with typed transcriptions. The letters span 1858 to 1866.
Conditions Governing Access
Open to users without restriction.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Gift of Mrs. Meyers and Mrs. George Blanthorn, 1965.
